The ECAD acts upon the request by making recommendations to OSAS and informing the requesting organization of the approval status. Project proponents must inform ECAD of any intended changes two days prior to the presentation. Five days after the activity, proponents are required to submit documentation for record purposes.

category: Article XIV - Right to Proper Information
content: Under Article XIV Right to Proper Information, Sections 1 through 3 reiterate the protocols for cultural programs. Every proposed cultural program or activity must pursue the objectives of the Academe and requires prior clearance from the Office of the President through the Office of Student Affairs and Services (OSAS). Any bonafide faculty, administrative employee, or student desiring to present a cultural activity must submit a letter of request, tentative program, production staff list, and budget estimates to OSAS through the EARIST Cultural Affairs Division (ECAD) and IGP Office.

category: Article XIV - Right to Proper Information
topic: Posting on Official Social Media Accounts
content:
Under Article XIV Right to Proper Information, the Institute outlines guidelines for Posting of Advertisement Materials on Official Social Media Accounts. EARIST uses social media to supplement marketing efforts and encourages students to share Institute news. However, students mentioning EARIST or sharing its information are automatically considered representatives of the Institute and must understand the implications of their posts.

The Institute reserves the right to request the removal of content from an official social media account if it poses a risk to the reputation of the Institute, its employees, or students. Permission to post digital materials is granted subject to specific conditions: the press must not be used for unlawful or divisive purposes, and materials must not violate contemporary ethical or moral standards. Procedurally, all digital materials and announcements must bear the signature of the SAS Director and be endorsed to the Information and Public Affairs Services (InfoPAS) Director for posting.

category: Article XIV - Right to Proper Information
topic: Installation of Advertisement Materials on Campus
content:
Under Article XIV Right to Proper Information, permits to post announcements within school premises are subject to strict guidelines. All announcements must bear the signature of the SAS Director before posting and are restricted to bulletin boards or designated areas approved by the SAS Office. The SAS Director reserves the right to approve or reject the kind of announcement to be posted.

Content requirements dictate that posters must not violate ethical or moral standards and must be neat, clean, clear, and concise, avoiding excessive aesthetics. Posters must indicate the name of the responsible individual, group, or organization. The responsible party is liable for removing the posters after they have served their purpose and for any damage to the posting area. Furthermore, permits to install banners or tarpaulins are granted only upon compliance with prescribed conditions.

category: Article XIV - Right to Proper Information
topic: Use of EARIST Logo and Trademarks
content:
Under Article XIV Right to Proper Information, strict rules govern the Use of EARIST Logo and Trademarks. Any individual, group, or organization wishing to use or imitate the EARIST Logo, or use a strikingly similar seal in documents, goods, or services, must secure a permit from the Information and Public Affairs Services (InfoPAS) Office. 

Specific approval from InfoPAS is required for the use or selling of the logo on products, merchandise, or services distributed to the public. This applies to three categories: 1) Institutional collateral such as calling cards, brochures, and letterheads; 2) Souvenir items or merchandise like jackets, t-shirts, mugs, and stickers; and 3) Institutional advertisements including posters, billboards, print ads, and electronic ads.

Under Article XV, the Office of the International Affairs Service (OIAS) serves as the technical secretariat assisting the academe in implementing education, student mobility, and internship matters involving international organizations. OIAS coordinates all international dimensions of EARIST in compliance with CHED Memorandum Order 55, Series of 2016.

Section 1 defines International Linkages, including: the Exchange Visitors Program (Mutual Education and Cultural Exchange Act); the Cultural Exchange Program (promoting mutual understanding via exchange of students/artists); the Study Abroad Program; and Academic Short Courses leading to degrees or certificates. Section 2 defines International Internship as the application of classroom learning to actual work abroad (commercial, industrial, government, or non-government) for the purpose of completing an academic degree, with a duration ranging from six (6) months to one (1) year.

Under Article XVI Effectivity, the Student Handbook takes effect immediately upon approval by the Board of Trustees. The policies and regulations contained within the handbook apply to all bona fide students of the Institute.

topic: EARIST Hymn, Inang Paaralan, and Pledge of Loyalty
content:
The EARIST Hymn lyrics are as follows: 'Let the EARIST music fill the air, With the echo our spirit rise. There's a magic that will stir the hearts When we sing our lively, tuneful march. What a joy to sing the music gay, When it sounds with a beat of martial air. Let the call of duty we obey, And the service we give every day. EARIST, your name is in our hearts, EARIST, our love will always spark. We pledge to stand by you, thru our Noble thoughts and deeds, To give you our love and loyalty forever. E.A.R.I.S.T. – EARIST, Forever!'

The Inang Paaralan (Alma Mater Song) lyrics are: 'Ating lilisanin, Paaralan, Inang Paaralan, Paaralang mahal. Kamag-aral at mga guro, Gunita sa tuwina'y Laging alaala, Lalagi sa dibdib. Kami'y pinagpala, Tapos na ang aral. Sa aming paglisan, Ngunit itiya'y simula Tungo sa tagumpay, Pagsisikap sa buhay. Paalam, paalam, Paaralang Mahal, Hanggang magtagumpay. Inang Paaralan, Rodriguez, naming mahal.'

The Pledge of Loyalty states: 'With all sincerity and freedom from pride, I hereby pledge my loyalty to my School and reiterate my love to my Country and people. To my Alma Mater, I solemnly promise to hold high its ideals and keep its noble traditions. I will strive with others to share all the knowledge and power that I have at my command, so necessary in the reconstruction of our nation’s economy. And finally, I resolve with a sober sense of responsibility to dedicate myself to the service of the Republic and the well-being of its citizenry. May God bless our Alma Mater and its graduates forever.'

Under the Definition of Terms section, the following terms are defined for academic and administrative contexts:

Absent refers to the act of not being present in a class. An Academic Degree is a course of study in a particular educational institution. Academic Honors are awards given to students with distinction, such as Summa, Magna, or Cum Laude. Academic Load is the number of subjects or courses a student is enrolled in. An Academic Program is a course or study taken at an educational institution. Accreditation is a concept based on self-regulation, focusing on evaluation and the continuous improvement of educational quality. Activity refers to something done that involves a group of people. Admission is the act of admitting or allowing a student to enroll. Attendance is the act of being physically present in class.

A Baccalaureate Degree refers to any four- or five-year program of study. A Class is a series of meetings where students are taught a particular subject or activity, or a group of students instructed together. College refers to the tertiary level of education. A Complaint is a verbal or written statement expressing dissatisfaction. Conduct refers to the way a person behaves in a particular place or situation. Cross Enroll means to enroll in courses from one school while attending another. Curriculum is the systematic sequence of courses required for graduation. Dean is the person appointed in charge of a college. Director is a person who manages or supervises an institution. Discipline refers to control requiring rules to be obeyed. Dismissal is the discharge or removal from enrollment. Doctor refers to a person with a doctoral degree. Dropped refers to withdrawal from a course within a given period. Dropped Grade is a grade given to a student who voluntarily dropped a course at least two weeks after classes started. Examination is a test to assess progress. Expulsion is forcibly removing a student from an institution with justifiable cause. Failed Grade is a grade given to a student who does not meet passing requirements.

Under the Definition of Terms section, the following terms are defined:

Fee is an amount of money to be paid for enrollment or services in a given semester. Fifth Year refers to a student in their fifth year of study. Final Examination is an examination given before the end of a school term. Form is a printed document to be completed by anyone in the institution. Freshman is a first-year student. Grade is a mark given to a student reflecting academic performance. Graduate refers to a student who has successfully completed a level of education and earned a degree. Incomplete Grade (INC) is a temporary grade given to a student who may qualify for passing but has not fulfilled all requirements of a subject.

Institutional Student Programs and Services are designs to proactively respond to the basic health, food, shelter, and safety needs of all types of students. An Irregular Student is one who carries less than the full load and/or has back subjects required in a given semester. Junior is a third-year student. Master's refers to a master’s degree. Midterm Examination is given in the middle of the semester. Miscellaneous refers to additional fees aside from tuition fees. Offense is something that is wrong or improper. Official is a person who holds an office in an educational institution.

Paying Students are defined as students who are overstaying, not able to finish their program within the prescribed period, and considered ineligible to avail of free tertiary education. Penalty is a punishment for breaking a rule. Policy refers to rules or procedures to be observed. President is the head of the school. Probation is a situation where a person who made a serious mistake is placed under supervision.

topic: Terms O to V (OJT to Vocational)
content:
Under the Definition of Terms section, the following terms are defined:

On-the-Job Training / Practicum / Internship / Immersion is a requirement for graduating students prescribed in the school’s curriculum. Organization refers to an organized group or body for a particular course or purpose. Rectification of Grades is the process of correcting incorrect entries in academic records. Refund is the return of certain fees within a prescribed period. Registration is the act of entering information into official records. Registrar is the officer in charge of registering students and maintaining academic records. Retention is the continued enrollment in school from one academic year to the next. Returnee is a student who failed or left a particular year level and wishes to be re-admitted.

Scholarship is financial assistance provided to defray educational expenses. School is an institution recognized by the state that undertakes educational operations. Senior is a fourth-year student. Shifter is a student who changes from one course to another. Sophomore is a second-year student. Special Student is a student enrolled at the tertiary level who is not earning formal academic credits. Student refers to a person currently enrolled and attending classes regularly. Student Handbook is the publication containing rules and policies.

Student Affairs and Services (SAS) are programs designed to complement student academic experiences and promote well-being. Student Welfare Services are basic services for well-being. Student Development Services are programs for student formation and discipline. Substitution is the act of replacing one thing with another. Suspension is the act of temporarily forcing a student to leave school due to an offense. Teacher is a person employed to guide learning experiences. Tertiary Students are those who enjoy free tertiary education and are enrolled in undergraduate degrees. Tenure is the length of stay of a student in the institution. Transcript of Records is the official record of grades. Transferee is a student entering from another school. Tuition is money paid for the right to study. Undergraduate is a student who has not yet earned a degree. Violation is the act of doing something not allowed by rule. Vocational relates to special skills or training for a job.
